c. 1890 -  see comments at the related photos -

The buildings were resumed and demolished for the creation of Martin Place,  previously Moore Street.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
Wow I didn't know that, thanks BC.
Martin Place figuratively speaking no doubt, as it remained a street for quite a while more?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] This is more complicated than I imagined. The road between George and Pitt Streets was known as "St Martin's Lane"; and "Moore Street" between Pitt and Castlereagh Streets (see 1880 map) "St Martin's Lane" became "Martin Place" and "Moore Street" stayed (see 1895 map). I am not yet sure when the whole street became known as Martin Place, maybe not until the 1920s when it was knocked right through to Macquarie Street. How very confusing! Interesting detailed article about the 'new' street, including the compensation payments to Palings etc - SMH 11/05/1892 p.8 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13843677 .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/] Ahem! It is 356 George Street, and on Photo Investigator. All very confusing ...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This is another good pic which shows the beams left in the clock tower for hoisting the bells. The beams were evidently placed by the contractors who removed the scaffolding after the tower was completed towards the end of 1885. The scaffolding was evidently removed by mid March 1886. For further info and references see - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2554622065/
